IN AN wrap-span">ARTICLE published in 2012 wrap-span">John Preskill, a wrap-span">theoretical wrap-span">physicist, posed a question: “Is controlling large-scale wrap-span">quantum systems merely really, really hard, or is it wrap-span">ridiculously hard?” wrap-span">Seven years later the answer is in: it is merely really, really hard.

wrap-span">Last week a paper on wrap-span">The matter was—briefly and wrap-span">presumably wrap-span">accidentally—published online. wrap-span">The wrap-span">underlying research had already been accepted by wrap-span">Nature, a top-tier wrap-span">scientific journal, but was still under wraps. wrap-span">The leak wrap-span">revealed that Google has achieved what Dr Preskill wrap-span">dubbed in his article, “wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">supremacy”. Using a wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">computer, researchers at wrap-span">The information-technology giant had carried out in a wrap-span">smidgen over three minutes a wrap-span">calculation that would take wrap-span">Summit, wrap-span">The world’s current-best classical superwrap-span">computer, 10,000 years to wrap-span">execute.

A wrap-span">credible wrap-span">demonstration of wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">supremacy, which few disagree that wrap-span">The leaked paper wrap-span">represents, is indeed a wrap-span">milestone. It will divide wrap-span">The history of wrap-span">The field into two eras: a “before”, when wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">computers were swrap-span">imply hoped to outpace even wrap-span">The best classical kind, and an “after”, when wrap-span">They actually did so. wrap-span">There has been much talk, including in this newspaper, about wrap-span">The latter era. wrap-span">Now it has arrived.

wrap-span">Leaping forward

Google’s experiment was “wrap-span">circuit sampling”: checking whewrap-span">Ther numbers wrap-span">Their machine spits out, given random inputs, fit a particular pattern. wrap-span">This wrap-span">niche task was chosen to be easy for a wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">computer while still being wrap-span">checkable—just—by a classical one. It does, though, confirm that wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">computers may in time be able to handle long-standing matters of wrap-span">practical wrap-span">importance. wrap-span">These include designing new drugs and materials, giving a boost to wrap-span">The field of machine learning, and making wrap-span">obsolete wrap-span">The wrap-span">cryptographic codes that lock up some of wrap-span">The world’s secrets.

wrap-span">Quantum wrap-span">computers employ three wrap-span">counterwrap-span">intuitive phenomena. wrap-span">One is “superpowrap-span">sition”, the idea behind Schrödinger’s famous dead-and-alive cat. wrap-span">Unwrap-span">like classical bits, which must be either wrap-span">One or zero, “qubits” may be a wrap-span">mixture of both. Google’s machine has 53 qubits, which between them can wrap-span">represent nearly ten million billion possible wrap-span">superposed wrap-span">states.

wrap-span">The second is “wrap-span">wrap-span">entanglement”, which ties wrap-span">Quantum wrap-span">particles togewrap-span">Ther across time and space. In standard wrap-span">computers each bit is wrap-span">rigorously wrap-span">sequestered from wrap-span">The next. wrap-span">Quantum machines wrap-span">like wrap-span">Their qubits wrap-span">wrap-span">entangled. wrap-span">Mawrap-span">Thematical operations on wrap-span">superposed and wrap-span">wrap-span">entangled qubits can act, to a greater or wrap-span">lesser degree, on all of wrap-span">Them at once.

A wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">calculation starts by addressing qubits wrap-span">individually: making one of them mostly zero, say, and then entangling it with its neighbour by a certain amount. wrap-span">That done, it lets the rules of wrap-span">physics play out, with the qubits’ wrap-span">states and wrap-span">linkages evolving over time. At the end (but not before, which would ruin the wrap-span">calculation), the qubits are examined wrap-span">simultaneously to obtain an answer.

wrap-span">The trick is to maximise wrap-span">The chance of choosing wrap-span">The right answer instead of one of wrap-span">The zillions of wrong ones. wrap-span">This is where wrap-span">The third counterwrap-span">intuitive idea comes in. In classical wrap-span">physics, probabilities must be powrap-span">sitive—a 30% chance of rain, say. wrap-span">Quantum wrap-span">mechanics uses a related concept, called “wrap-span">amplitudes”. wrap-span">These can be wrap-span">negative as well as powrap-span">sitive. By ensuring that wrap-span">amplitudes which wrap-span">represent wrong answers cancel each owrap-span">Ther out, while those that wrap-span">represent wrap-span">The right one wrap-span">reinforce, programmers can home in with high confidence on wrap-span">The correct solution.

wrap-span">That is the explanation which textbooks present, anyway. In the laboratory, things are rather more difficult. wrap-span">Superpowrap-span">sitions and wrap-span">wrap-span">entanglements are wrap-span">exceedingly wrap-span">delicate phenomena. wrap-span">Even the jiggling of wrap-span">adjacent wrap-span">molecules can wrap-span">interrupt them and wrap-span">sully a wrap-span">calculation. wrap-span">Most designs for wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">computers require the machines to be stored at temperatures wrap-span">colder than wrap-span">That of deep space, and to be tended by a wrap-span">basement full of PhDs, to keep things on track.

No height of education or depth of cold, though, can altogewrap-span">Ther wrap-span">preclude errors wrap-span">creeping in. wrap-span">The biggest problem facing wrap-span">quantum engineers is how to spot and correct wrap-span">These, because most of wrap-span">The useful applications of wrap-span">quantum computing will require many, many more qubits than current devices sport—with a wrap-span">concomitant increase in wrap-span">The risk of errors. wrap-span">That has wrap-span">spurred a huge effort, both by well-known firms such as wrap-span">IBM, wrap-span">Intel and wrap-span">Microsoft, and by an wrap-span">eager band of newcomers, such as Rigetti, to build better, less error-wrap-span">prone kit.

wrap-span">There is also, in wrap-span">parallel with wrap-span">This race to build better machines, a race to wrap-span">Develop useful wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">algorithms to run on wrap-span">Them. wrap-span">The most famous example so far is probably Shor’s wrap-span">algorithm. wrap-span">This is wrap-span">The piece of wrap-span">quantum-turbocharged maths that allows rapid factorisation of large numbers into wrap-span">Their wrap-span">component primes, and thus scares wrap-span">cryptographers, a group whose trade depends on wrap-span">This being a hard thing to do. wrap-span">But if wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">computers are really to earn wrap-span">Their keep, wrap-span">Then owrap-span">Ther wrap-span">algorithms will be needed. wrap-span">Developing wrap-span">Them will be wrap-span">assisted by wrap-span">The fact that a lot of wrap-span">The wrap-span">proposed applications (drug design, materials science and so on) wrap-span">Themselves depend on wrap-span">quantum processes. wrap-span">This, indeed, is why those applications have been so wrap-span">intractable until now.

wrap-span">Little wrap-span">acorns

wrap-span">Despite the promise of wrap-span">quantum computing, many in the field are uncomfortable with the wrap-span">phrase “wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">supremacy”, for it wrap-span">implies a wrap-span">threshold that, once crossed, leaves decades of existing wrap-span">computer science in the wrap-span">dust for something wrap-span">weird wrap-span">And wonderful. wrap-span">And for all the “before” wrap-span">And “after” that Google’s paper wrap-span">represents, building wrap-span">practical, error-corrected machines will be far from easy.

It is wrap-span">Therefore a mistake, most people think, to believe that wrap-span">quantum computing will replace wrap-span">The classical sort. wrap-span">The wrap-span">practicalities of low-temperature operation alone are wrap-span">likely to see to this. wrap-span">Governments, big firms and wrap-span">The wrap-span">richer sorts of univerwrap-span">sity will, no doubt, buy wrap-span">Their own machines. wrap-span">Owrap-span">Thers will rent time on devices linked to wrap-span">quantum versions of wrap-span">The cloud. wrap-span">But wrap-span">The total number of wrap-span">quantum wrap-span">computers will be limited.

wrap-span">And that will be fine. wrap-span">But it is worth bearing in mind a similar wrap-span">prediction of limited demwrap-span">And made in the early days of classical computing. In 1943 wrap-span">Thomas wrap-span">Watson, then boss of wrap-span">IBM, is wrap-span">alleged to have said, “I think there is a world market for maybe five wrap-span">computers.” He was out by a factor of perhaps a billion.
